JERUSALEM  —   Shimon Peres, the Israeli former prime minister and president who shared a Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to resolve the   conflict with the Palestinians, remained hospitalized on Wednesday after suffering what his doctor called a “massive stroke.
He had been hospitalized twice after suffering chest pains.
Peres was rushed to the hospital in   after suffering a minor heart attack.

Here’s more from the Times of Israel: Earlier this month, Peres underwent surgery to receive an artificial pacemaker, after he was diagnosed with an abnormal heart rhythm in July following a series of minor health scares.
Mr Peres suffered a small heart attack this year and had a pacemaker implanted a week ago to deal with an irregular heart beat.

In a career spanning nearly seven decades, Peres, 93, served in a dozen cabinets and twice as a Labour Party prime minister, even though he never won a general election outright in five tries from 1977 to 1996.
Peres has held virtually every senior political office in Israel over a   career, including three terms as prime minister as well as stints as foreign minister and finance minister.
He served as prime minister twice, from 1984 to 1986, and after the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin in 1995.
Peres served in almost every major position in Israeli government over his more than six decades in political life: He was prime minister twice, and interim prime minister twice, as well.
Mr Peres later served as president of Israel, a more ceremonial post, from 2007 to 2014.
Peres has remained active since completing his   term as president in 2014, and is one of the country’s most popular public figures.
In Israeli politics for more than half a century, Peres retired from public office in 2014 after his   term as president ended.
Peres became president in 2007 for one   term.
According to The Associated Press, he served three terms as prime minister and held the posts of foreign minister and finance minister.
By then, he had been in Israeli politics for more than half a century, holding virtually every position in Israel’s Cabinet, from minister of defense to prime minister, a position he held twice.
He was an important player in developing Israel’s military, including its nuclear program, and he served in multiple governments as defense minister and foreign minister.

Peres shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Israel’s late prime minister Yitzhak Rabin and late Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat for a 1993 interim peace deal that they and their successors failed to turn into a durable treaty.

In 1994, Peres was jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize with   Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat for their efforts in negotiating the Oslo Accord, the first interim peace agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
